<answer>



Amelia, Kate or Skye would be my pick



Jay is too boyish and may be mistaken too often for a little girls liking, Harley for the same reason, and Aikah would be mispronounced way too often and is too off beat.



Amelia Kate or Amelia Skye is pretty.

<answer>



Hum...well..



All the "Alexis, Alexa's" etc, that I know are whores...so No on that one.



My name is Nicole...I have allways hated it. Its so boring.



Miley? Are you a 14 year old Hannah Montana fan?



Aiden- is WAYYYY too popular right now.



Angelica/Gabriella- is too ethnic/steriotypical



Eden- sounds like a hippy name



I like Milan...but again, thats kinda Trendy.



If you used these Names, be prepaired for your child to come home from school and make you write your last name on all her stuff too...because there is going to be a billion other little girls with the same "orginal" name. There are 3(!) little girls named Abby on my block, and 2 Aidens.



</answer>

Wow! Lots of names there!



Anyway, I like the names Alexis, Grace and Eden.
I think Alexis Lee works well, better than the other combinations.
Alexandra Lee works best.



Miley Nicole works better than Miley Grace.
I like Eden Elizabeth, nice mixture :)
Alaina Marie is better than Alaina Nicole
Hate the name Milan
I like Ariana, but prefer it spelt Arianna



Don't like either Luana or Loana
Dislike Stella, Angela, Angelica and Angelina
Some nice names in there, and some I don't like so much :)

<answer from>



Veronica Alicia
Member since: 06 May 2007
Total points: 40590 (Level 7)



</answer from>



<answer>



I like Alex - my grandson's second name.  He has a 3rd name which is Benjamin which we've traced back through the family as far as the 1600's.
My favourite names have links with history and especially family history so my second name "Alicia" is for my mother, Alice.  She was named for her mother Eliza Lavinia who was named for her mother, Eliza.  Eliza's mum was Elizabeth and hers was another Alicia.
Alex, of course, is for the family tradition and the closest my daughter could find to Alice, her grandmother.



</answer>

thelover...

<answer>



if indians then-
girl-ananya,latika,lovanya&avni are the best names.
boy-dheirya,kunal,vansh&ansh are the best names.



if from abroad then-
girl-Adisa – Origin is Ashanti of Ghana, meaning “the one will teach us”,,Aysel – Turkish origin, meaning “moonlight”
,,Naima – Swedish origin, meaning “tranquility”,,Naira – Quechuan and Aymaran origin, meaning “large eyes”are the best names.



boy-Morgandy – Celtic origin, meaning “a little one from the sea’s edge”,,Morgandy – Celtic origin, meaning “a little one from the sea’s edge”,,Eolande – Celtic origin, meaning “violet flower” are the best names



Source(s):



mind!



</answer>

<answer>



u should give a good name to ur baby the good names are------



if indians then-
girl-ananya,latika,lovanya&avni are the best names.
boy-dheirya,kunal,vansh&ansh are the best names.



if from abroad then-
girl-Adisa – Origin is Ashanti of Ghana, meaning “the one will teach us”,,Aysel – Turkish origin, meaning “moonlight”
,,Naima – Swedish origin, meaning “tranquility”,,Naira – Quechuan and Aymaran origin, meaning “large eyes”are the best names.



boy-Morgandy – Celtic origin, meaning “a little one from the sea’s edge”,,Morgandy – Celtic origin, meaning “a little one from the sea’s edge”,,Eolande – Celtic origin, meaning “violet flower” are the best names

<question>



Name dilema... my 1st daughters' name is Kendra.?



My wife & I just found out we are expecting our second baby girl.  We are having some trouble agreeing on a name and have even more trouble just trying to come up with more names.  Our first child is named Kendra, we would either like to stay with the 'K' (sound/ so 'C' is okay) or have the "ah" sound at the end.  Can you suggest any names?



The only name as of right now that we both somewhat agree on and are considering is Colleen, what do you think?



</question>



<additional details>



Okay Mark, let me tell you a little something.  I don't care if you think it's cute or dumb or lame and etc., I was asking for opinions on names not what you thought about naming my kids by the same sound in the beginning or the end.  How disrespectful people can be... Can I ask you something?  What are your kids' name?  North Dakota & South Dakota?  GROW UP!



Just another suggestion, Mark, why not trying to go back to school?  In these day and ages, we like to spell things out and spell them right.  That's what grown-ups do anyhow.



MAK*** (kept saying Mark) --- either way, you should consider taking my advice.



</additional details>



<answer from>



sheridan...
Member since: 29 September 2008
Total points: 671 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



I really like the name Colleen, I haven't heard the name since back to Pre-K/ Kindergarten.



Some other names could be Kathryn, Kaitlyn, Kasey, Kaylen, Kristie, Kaydence, Kylie, Kaylie, Krista or Alina, Alisha, Bianca, Breanna, Daniella, Hannah, Julia, Alexa, Miranda, Olivia, Patricia, Samantha, Tanya, Vanessa.



</answer>

<answer from>



Ginnie
Member since: 14 May 2008
Total points: 1169 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



I love the name Colleen! It's my mom's name, and my daughter's middle name. It's very unique as well. Since it seems like you prefer Irish names (so do I), here are some other suggestions:
Keaira/Ceara/Ciara (pronounced kee-ra)
Kella
Kerra
Cadhla (pronounced Kyla)
Clodagh (pronounced cloud-uh)
Clidhna (pronounced kleena)
Karah (pronounced kara)
Keilah (pronounced kay-lah)
Here are other Irish names starting with C or K, but not ending in ah or a:
Cathleen
Caitlin
Cassidy
Carrigan



Keeran/Kieran
Kenadie/Kennedy
Kevine (pronounced kev-een)
Kiley
Here are Irish names ending with a or ah sound, but not beginning with C or K:
Ownah (can be pronounced on-ah or oo-nah)
Nola
Phiala (pronounced fee-la)
Orlaith (pronounced Orla)



I really hope I helped!! These are all beautiful, unique names and would sound lovely with Kendra!!! GOOD LUCK!!!



</answer>

<answer>



What about Ciara (pronounced Kee-rah) it begins with a C and ends with the 'ah' sound.



There are also many alternative spellings of the name: Keera, Kiara, Khera ...



I think Kendra is an interesting name: it is unusual but not difficult to pronounce. Maybe try thinking along the same lines or looking up similar sounding names on a baby name website. Good luck.



P.S. I like Colleen too.

<answer from>



bkdaniel...
Member since: 18 November 2006
Total points: 1145 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Have you ever heard of the lost books of the Bible? Basically, they were Christian" writings composed between 200 BC and AD 200, but  were never considered scripture? Well there is one, in general, that I found quite intresting called The Wisdom of Solomon. In it the writer talks about wisdom. Here's what I think would make a great name for a female.



He says, "WISDOM IT WAS..." ...she saved him after his fall..." He goes on to say other great things about wisdom. He say's "Wisdom I loved; I sought her out when I was young and longed to win her for my bride, and I fell in love with her beauty...," "because it is given her to live with God, and the Lord of all things has accepted her.," and "She is initiated into the knowledge that belongs to God, and she decides for him what he shall do."



What wonderful words to say about wisdom. And that is why I find it appealing to make Wisdom a name. What do you think?



Source(s):



1. CHRISTIAN APOLOGETICS & RESEARCH MINISTRY, 2006. The Wisdom of Solomon. NEW ENGLISH BIBLE, Oxford University Press, http://www.carm.org/lost/solomon.htm.



</answer>

<original file>17116.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk107326.txt</current file name>




<category>



Pregnancy & Parenting



Baby Names



</category>



<question from>



My name Isobel.
Member since: 16 February 2008
Total points: 7046 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Baby Names



</question from>



<question>



What is your ONE favorite name for a boy and a girl?



Rules:
1. Only give out ONE name (NOT even a middle name) for each gender.
2. Choose ONE name for a GIRL; Choose ONE name for a boy.



Example:
"My favorites are:
girl: Miriam
boy: Bennett"



</question>

LEDIA

</answer from>



<answer>



Elliot is rank 359 last year for boys
Ellott is rank 389 last year for boys
It get's more common for a for boys each year



Why name you daughter a name that people think is a boy, and a name that is becoming trendy with boys again?



Emerson is a boys name, it was rank 312 for girl name last year.  Emerson was rank 494 last year in boys name
I would name a girl a boys name like this.  It could be either
Emerson Clair.



It's you child do what you want



Jeremy Scott is fine for a boy.  I like Elliott Scott better for a boy, not my child



</answer>

Aisling/Aishlilng/Ashling-gaelic means dream
Anming-chinese-peaceful clarity
Biming-chinese-the clearty of jade
Jing -chinese-crystal,



Ling-chinese-delicate
Ming-chinese-shining; tomorrow
Ping-fair
Spring-english-do not like this name
Starling-name of a bird
Sterling-I know a women with this name, it's a family name past down form the 1700's.  It is listed as a boys name.  The only person I ever met was this women with this name

<answer>



starting with guys:
my favorite one is Liam Daniel. I LOVE the name Liam. Kristopher would be better spelled with a "Ch" i think, b/c it looks a lot like Kris Kringle as Kristopher.... lol. But Kristopher Mitchell is also a fantastic option. The other ones I don't like at all. ='(



girls:



I like Lilah Frances a lot, and Elaina Renee is pretty too. Quinn reminds me of a guy [even though I knew a girl named Quinn too] Lillianna Marie is GORGEOUS. Angeline Nicole sounds too much like Angelina Jolie. Katee... common name, different spelling; her name will ALWAYS be getting misspelled [same with Kristopher too, actually] micheala spelled like that will get misspelled; usually the a is in FRONT of the e... Lauren Ann Jane...kind of a mouthful.



it would be awesome if she named them Hayden (girl) and Cayden (boy). lol. =)



</answer>

<question>



Baby names - Does anyone have?



A nice form or nickname for Abraham? I love Bram but it does not work as a middle  name, and especially since first name is Dean.  Has anyone known of a name or someone with a different version of Abraham.  I want to honor a relative by using the name, Abraham, but doesn't Dean Abraham sound funny together?  I think it would need a more modern version?

</additional details>



<answer from>



MC the baby namer (McCain 08)

<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



It doesn't sound weird. You could use Abe, Abel, or Abram as a nickname.



</answer>



<asker's comment>

</asker's comment>



<answer from>



Diane M
Member since: 11 November 2007
Total points: 11725 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



Dean Abraham does not sound funny together, I think it sounds good. You could call him Bram (or spell it Brahm) even if his official name is Dean Abraham.
Name him the name that you want, and call him by the nickname that you want him to go by. There are all different kinds of nicknames, or names that people go by for whatever reason. We know who we are ;)
Don't worry !!



</answer>

<question>



Help with a baby girl name... we're expecting our second daughter.?



My husband & I are expecting our second child, a baby girl.  Our first little girl is named Kendra LeighAnn (named after both grandmother's).  Our second child we would like to name after a deceased Uncle; Stacy.  My husband loves the name Colleen, I also like this name but I think it's only OK.  Colleen Stacy?  I really like the name Melanie, but I know it doesn't sound good with the name Stacy ("EE" sound at the end of each name) so we are considering Melanie Anastasia?



I also don't want my Mother-In-Law thinking we named our second child after her as well, her middle name is Leigh.  She is not a part of our lives anymore so I don't want her to feel "honored" because the "LEE" sound is in Colleen.



I also like Melanie because it has the "ANN" sound in there, I want to name my second daughter after my Mom just as I did my first daughter.



Which do you think sounds better, put together?
Colleen Stacy or Melanie Anastasia... also remember our first daughters' name.



</question>



<additional details>



I might add we have a VERY short last name, one 1 syllable.  I'd like to believe my MIL wouldn't assume we'd named our daughter after her if choosing Colleen, although we have a Kylie & Kallie and supposedly they're both named after her, however the mothers' of these children have very different opinions.



& Stacy is the nickname post given to the name Anastasia.



</additional details>

<question from>



trini38

Total points: 118 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



My daughter is pregnant do u think shyanne s a pretty name for my grandchild if its a girl?



</question>



<answer from>



Emιly Mαrια
Member since: 06 July 2008
Total points: 5416 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Baby Names



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Spell it like Cheyenne or Shianne. My sister's friend has the name Shianne, spelled that way. I love the name, but remember -- This is your daughter's child, not yours. You got to name her and any siblings of hers. This is her turn. Suggest Cheyenne (Shianne), then leave it be.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



as the grandmother i did suggest those 2 spellings of the name but mother rules



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



rubybenu...
Member since: 12 May 2008
Total points: 5707 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



...no...



1) I'm not fond of taking the name of a people and transforming it into "cute" name. Why call a child "Cheyenne" but not "Nez Perce" (a Pacific Northwest tribe). It just seems disrespectful.



2) Shyanne/Shy-anne/Shian/Shianne are ghastly and look illiterate. If your daughter is determined to use the name, at least she should use the traditional spelling.



</answer>



<answer from>



Heather
Member since: 12 June 2007
Total points: 5735 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



It's spelled Cheyenne (don't try to be "creative" by coming up with ridiculous spellings) and I think the name is just OK - not awful not great, but the spelling Shyanne makes it terrible.



</answer>



<answer from>



Love♥
Member since: 18 December 2007
Total points: 21324 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



Yes it's pretty but Cheyenne is the classic spelling (like the city) and if you do a weird spelling she'll be correcting people all her life.



</answer>

<question from>



Victoria
Member since: 31 October 2008
Total points: 130 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Is the name Dean short for Deano?



this has been bugging me i love the name Dean but dont like Deano is Dean short for Deano or can it just be Dean???



</question>



<additional details>



sorry i mean Dino



</additional details>



<answer from>



rubybenu...
Member since: 12 May 2008
Total points: 5707 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



DEAN  Gender: Masculine



Usage: English



Pronounced: DEEN



From a surname which means either "valley" from Middle English dene or else "dean" from Middle English deen (ultimately from Latin decanus meaning "chief of ten").



DINO  Gender: Masculine



Usage: Italian



Pronounced: DEE-no
Short form of names ending in dino, such as BERNARDINO.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



thank u



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



foschizl...
Member since: 31 October 2007
Total points: 1630 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



no - it's not - in fact, Deano is a rarely used *nickname* for Dean.



edit:  the more common spelling of Deano is actually "Dino"....



oddly enough, Dean Martin (a popular singer way back) was actually given the birth name of Dino, but changed it to Dean.



</answer>



<answer from>



I'm Excited for Winter!
Member since: 08 September 2008
Total points: 4951 (Level 4)

<answer>



Max Simeon
Max Simon
Max Samuel

Max Sullivan
Max Solomon
Max Samson
Max Seamus

<category>



Pregnancy & Parenting



Baby Names



</category>



<question from>



Mummy to be - 12th March 09 xx
Member since: 29 August 2008
Total points: 3200 (Level 4)



Contributing In:



Pregnancy



</question from>



<question>



Baby names.... Opinions pleease??! xx ?



I am 22 weeks pregnant and my partner and I have decided on the following names:



Hollie Kate (Girl)
River Stanley (Boy)



I love the names as they reflect our personalities but I am worried about what other people will think. Do other mums worry about this?! Should I even care what other people think?! What do u think??!



Thanks xx



</question>



<additional details>



Aww thanks for your lovely answers =] I asked this question about 8 weeks ago and people were so rude I was scared to ask it again =]



xx



</additional details>



<answer from>



soccer is life
Member since: 28 June 2008
Total points: 2190 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



I absolutely adore Hollie Kate and River Stanley is a great, unique boy's name!  It is definitely up to you what you name your children, and I think the names are beautiful!  Good luck with everything!



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Thank you very much xx



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



coolteamblt -James is due 21.12!
Member since: 19 September 2007
Total points: 15710 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Baby Names



</answer from>



<answer>



The only thing I would change is the spelling of Hollie. It's a word in the dictionary, and it's spelled Holly. I like how the modern feel of River is balanced by Stanley, and I like the overall sound of both names. I just think that if you're going to use a word in the dictionary, it needs to be spelled the right way! Ivie looks silly, Ivy looks correct.



I worry to some extent what people think of the name I've picked, but I'm not going to change it because someone tells me they don't like it! If they have a valid concern, like it made a curse word with my last name (Mike Hunt or something like that), or it was just a poor choice of name (like Prehshusse or Timablynnd), I would consider the opinion. What really matters is that you and your partner like the name, and that it will serve your child well throughout life.



</answer>



<answer from>



Hilarious, but Exhausted
Member since: 11 December 2006
Total points: 23190 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



It's not so much a question as to what you or other people will think,
You should most consider how your child is going to feel growing up with an  "off-the-wall" name like River or Stanley !!



Hollie Kate is very nice - an unusual pairing of two names but it works because they are normal names but don't hear them that often (which is what I imagine you want).  But, in my opinion (don't want to sound mean whatsover) and notice I said "my opinion" (and who, then, the heck am I?!) the boy names both have to GO.



How about Jack Phillipe  or Noah Benjamin  or  Samuel Carter  or Nathan Joseph?



Like the girl's name you have chosen the two names are familiar but when they are paired as first and middle names they become their own unique name creation.



Hope you don't mind my honesty and good luck with your upcoming baby - God bless !!



</answer>



<answer from>



Mummy of 4 soon to be 5 ~*~
Member since: 05 March 2008
Total points: 2191 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Personally I love them and really, when it comes down to it, thats all that has to matter. I named my daughter Charise Bethani (which everyone seemed to love) but when my son came along, we decided to call him Lucius Tiberius and everyone in the family was absolutely shocked by it (because it wasnt a common name or even remotely common sounding) but now, 3 yrs on, they love it... people love the idea that hes not just another Lachlan or Stuart...



Go with what you want and what you love! Goodluck!



</answer>

<answer>



It's fine. I don't have any strong feelings for it. I certainly don't hate it but it doesn't wow me either.



Pros: Timeless, potential nn Meg, easy spelling, works on all ages (not overly cutesy etc), can find items with your name on it (eg. mugs, pens)



Cons: Common, rather bland

<question>



Baby due March 24th... needs a name?



Hi ya'll!



I went to the doctor and he was unsure of the sex of our baby... our little one wouldn't give us a good enough glimpse. I need some suggestions on names! Any ideas?



I really like Benjamin Dillon or Samuel Dillon for a boy. Both names hold special significance to me personally. My fiance's twin brother, who brought me to church for the first time in high school when I was atheist and changed my life... his name is Benjamin. Their grandfather's name is Samuel. My younger brother's name is Dillon. We didn't grow up together and I missed seven years out of my brother's life, so I figured I would name my son after him... yeah, weird I know... but I like it. What do you all think about those names... and do you think it's weird naming a baby's first name after a brother like that?



Anyways, for a girl, I'm completely lost. I want something fairly common, but not overly used. I really like my own name (Amelia, but I go by Mia) and I'm looking for something that ages well. I like the middle names Grace and Rose, too.



Any ideas?



And btw... how far along do you think I look in my belly pic to the left?



=]



</question>

<answer>



I like the name Benjamin Dillon but it may be a little weird to name your son after his uncle and not his dad. People may get the wrong idea and think you picked the wrong brother.  Samuel Dillon has a nice ring to it.  I would go with that because it honors and carries on an elder of the family.



As for a girl name I've got ALOT :) ... Some of my favorite names along with their origin & meaning: (MN) - I like for a middle name, but some would work for a first name and vice versa :&gt;)



Aaralyn (AIR-a-lin) - American: "With song"
Ainsley - Scottish: "My own meadow"
Bailee (BAY-lee) - English: "Bailiff"
Caprice (ka-PREESE) - French: "whimsical, unpredictable"
Carrington - English: "Place name: Town of Cora"
Emberlyn - American: "Spark by the waterfall"
Fallon - Irish: "Of A Ruling Family"
Giselle (or Jazelle) - German: "Pledge"
Gracelyn - American: "Grace By The waterfall"
Harper - English: "Harpist, minstrel"
Harlow - English: "From The Mound Of The People"
Irelyn - American: "Homage To Ireland"
Hayden - English: "From The Hay Downs"
Jaelee - American: "Happy meadow"
Jacee - American: "The Flower"
Jacelyn - American: "Joyous"
Jazlyn - American: "Flower at the waterfall"
Kadance - English: "Rhythm"
Kailee(K-eye-lee) American: "Form of Kayla" (Arabic: "Crown")
Kalyn (KAY-lin) American: "Rejoicer by the waterfall"
Kennedy - Irish: "Helmeted chief"
Kenzington - Scottish: "The fair one"
Kinsley - English: "Offspring; relative"
Makenna - Scottish: "Ascend"
Marley - English: "Meadow near the lake"
Makailyn - American: "Pure"
Olivia - Form of Olga - Russian: "Holy"
Presley - English: "Priest's meadow"
Peyton - English: "Warrior's town"
Reagan - Irish: "Little ruller"
Saelee - American: "Blessed"
Saylor - American: "Strong, Brave one in Battle"
Sydney - English: "Wild Meadow"
Teagan - Irish: "Good Looking"



Avery (MN) - German: "noble; bearlike"
Belle (MN) - French: "Beautiful"
Dai (MN) - Japanese: "Great"
Kayde (MN) - Scottish: "Wetlands"
Kole (MN) - Greek: "Victorious people"
Laine (MN) - English: "Path"
Rayne (Rain) (MN) - Scandinavian: "Mighty"
Reese (MN) - Welsh: "Enthusiasm"
Shea (MN) - Gaelic: "Admirable"
Skye(MN) - Arabic: "Water giver"

Jamie
Member since: 25 December 2005
Total points: 2516 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



I like Benjamin Dillon. Benjamin is a great name that ages well, and it holds great significance to you. Samuel is nice too, but I prefer Benjamin. Have you considered Samuel Benjamin?



As for girls names, I like Rose and Amelia, but Grace is a tad overused (#20 most popular girls name in the US). Here are some other ideas for girls names:



Eve
Caroline
Hazel
Rachel
Elizabeth
Isabelle
Ivy
Abigail
Audrey
Violet
Josephine
Lydia
Julia
Alice
Bella
Lena
Clara
Madeleine
Cora
Stella



Hope I helped!



Source(s):



Books:



The Oxford Dictionary of First Names
The Baby Name Wizard by Laura Wattenberg



Websites:



http://www.behindthename.com/
http://www.namenerds.com/
http://www.nymbler.com/
http://www.babynamesworld.com/



</answer>

<answer>



Bailey isn't a girl's name. It's a surname and then a masculine boy's name. And yes, it's overused on poor little girls who are going to be gender confused.



Caitlin, spelled correctly, is the only decent one on the list.



Analei looks made up. Reese is masculine. I prefer Aisling to Ashlyn. Jaelyn looks made up. Demi is more of a nickname.



And I agree with your husband, Kynlei looks very made up, but then again, so does his favorite.



</answer>

<answer>



Hey!
Jamie is quite a common name for both boys and girls at the moment, so maybe you should choose something a little more unique! =)
I love the name Rory! It flows really well. It would suit a boy, and would suit him when he grows up as well. It's not very common, but most people know how to spell it.
I'm not sure about Rory Jay...it somehow doesn't look right...just my opinion! =)
Rory Lee is my choice, they both compliment each other and it is a lovely name!!



Hope I helped! =)

<question>



Baby due TOMORROW- Finalising name! HELP?



Hi! This is my 5th baby (i know, i'm tired!) and it is going to be a girl!



It was originally due today, but my due date was moved forward- i'm on bed rest at the moment although there are still no signs of her, shes gonna be a late one!



Already have 4 kids:
Emerald Lily (she is 14)
Ruby Violet (she is 2)
Garnet Rose (she is 6)
Jet Delphine (he is 10)



New baby:



We are very into the Gem/Flower theme.
Please don't be rude about this. These are a few names we have come up with, please choose just one! (last name Louelle)



Coral Poppy Louelle
Amethyst Jasmine Louelle
Opal Blossom Louelle
Pearl Marigold Louelle



Go ahead and swap the middle names and first names up!
Thanks very much.



</question>



<additional details>



It is now most likely to now be:



CORAL BLOSSOM LOUELLE



or



CORAL JASMINE LOUELLE.



And thankyou everyone with the support on the theme- other family and friend HATE it- but i love being original :)



</additional details>

<answer from>



Kelly P

Total points: 2680 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Favourite girls names - Emily (my daughters name), and actually quite like Ashlyn, don't like the names Imogen and Saffron.



Favourite boys names - Oliver, and Declan isn't bad, don't like the names Jed (too hillbilly) or Tor



</answer>



<answer from>



C S
Member since: 19 September 2008
Total points: 673 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Favourites:



Ashlyn*, Michaela, Nikita, Summer, Tierre



Connor, Isaac, Jed, Nicholas, Rory, Sebastian



Skye - not outright evil, but the girl might hate it later on.



Kaitlin - not a bad name, but the weird spelling will be inconvenient when everyone misspells her name
Ruby - I can't explain it, but I just don't like it.



Summer - not bad
Ashlyn - good - I particularly like this one
Jasmin - again, the strange spelling, and a bit too girly
Emily - not bad, but nothing special. If she looks like one, fine.



Indianna - no - she'll get hell in school with this name
Manaia - no - she'll get a lot of "mania" jokes
Ebony - it might be okay if she's dark-haired, but otherwise it'll end up being a joke
Michaila - try "Michaela", and then it'll be okay
Charlotte - not bad, but nothing special. Sounds old-fashioned
Imogen - er...what?



Isabel - again, not bad but nothing special
Clover - be forewarned about cow jokes. Seriously, that was the first thing that came to mind.



Nikita - not bad
Amethyst - no, too pretentious
Tierre - okay, if it suits her
Saffron - no...just no
Reilly - weird spelling, try "Riley"



BOYS (not in any order)
Declan - okay, if unusual
Archer - unless you want an "Archie", this leaves no room for nicknames.



Rory - quite good
Sebastian - quite good, but you'll probably have to pronounce the whole thing every time
Culver - no, it's just strange
Conner - make it "Connor" and it'll be okay
Tor - er...what? It's weird.



Nicholas - good, if a little common.



Cole - I just don't like it
Isaac - pretty good
Oliver - okay, but bad for nicknames
Samson - no
Jet - no - there will be a lot of jokes about it
Jed - pretty good
Pierre - not unless he's part French



</answer>



<answer from>



Xtina
Member since: 08 September 2008
Total points: 4836 (Level 4)



</answer from>

<answer from>



lt;3
Member since: 17 May 2008
Total points: 5374 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



1st - Joel and Leah. Both names are normal names, but they're not overused or trendy. They will work well for someone at all ages of their life.
2nd - Colin (no double i..it looks like a typo) and Alexis. They're a little more common, but they're still very nice names. They also work well at all ages.
3rd - Aaden and Madelyn - Aaden is much too common/overused. It might be a nice name, but it doesn't sound as great anymore when you know 12 people with that name. Madelyn is a beautiful name, but there are a million Maddie's.
4th - Hannah - Overused, but still a very nice name.
5th - Cara - A little boring, but not a bad name. What about Caroline?



</answer>



<answer from>

Member since: 15 April 2006

<answer>



Of those ones, my favorite is Cara.
I love how it is simple, sweet, and girly. It also has a great meaning - "friend".



I also like Colin (my favorite of the boy names) and Joel, as well as Aidan, Alexa, and Hana (only these spellings/variations though). I'm picky at names...



The only ones I don't like are Madelyn (too popular, also I can't stand the nn MADdy) and Leah (I knew a really creepy girl with this name, it ruined the name for me!)

<question from>



Allison F

</question from>



<question>



Is it ok to name my son after a character in Twilight?



My niece persuaded me to read the Twilight series,(and I did.) And while I was reading it I came across the name 'Carlisle' which I instantly fell in love with.



Do you think Carlisle James Fenwick is alright?? Would he get teased for having a name from Twilight?



My husband really likes it too.



</question>



<answer from>



whiteclo...

<question>



Dominic or Alexander?



Which do you prefer? Middle names either John or Richard - what sounds better....Dominic John? Dominic Richard? Alexander John? Do you think either of them are old fashioned or over used?



</question>



<answer from>



lisilu
Member since: 23 June 2008
Total points: 1155 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



I love Dominic and Alexander. I don't think Dominic is as prevalent as Alexander. I don't consider either one to be old fashioned. I guess it depends on the last name, but I prefer John.



</answer>

<answer>



When you think of names always think of what their friends will call them for short, for example Dominic John will be either DJ or Dom. Whilst Alexander John will never be AJ (it doesn't roll off the tongue) but he would be called Alex. The Richard part can be shortened to Dick so personally it wouldn't be a good idea. Neither are too old fashioned and at the end of the day its what you want that counts...



</answer>

<question from>

</question from>



<question>



Three names?



I have three names(my name is Jasmine Ana Elisabeth), and i was thinking about giving my baby three names as well.
What do you think of these names? and any sugesstions?

girls;
Ivy Maya Renee
Rinnan Naomi Anne
Elisaveta Sanya Kate(Elisaveta and Sanya are both Bosnian..and my boyfriend is half Bosnian)
Evageline Katherine Sarah
Esme Annabella Cadence

boys;
Thomas Leo(my boyfriend's father's name, and my boyfriend's grandfather)
Danvor Brayden Maxwell
Laurent Joshua Jaden
Hunter Wyatt Cruz
Jasper Reed Gael

thanks! and please be honest!



</question>



<answer from>



Abby B
Member since: 22 March 2008
Total points: 1727 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Ivy Maya Renee- VERY cute!! It is flowy and is a really pretty name. LOVE IT!!
Rinnan Naomi Anne- I'm not really sure how to pronounce the first name, but I do know that there are too many N's in a row. If you end up with this one, at least change the second one to something without an N (not sure about any suggestions becasause I don't know how to say the first name.)
Elisaveta Saynya Kate- LOVE IT!! I usually don't like kate as a middle name but it is soo cute here. I love the Bosnian names!! VERY cute!!
Evangeline Katherine Sarah- SOOOOO cute!! I love all the names. I love them together. They flow and make a perfect name!!
Esme Annabella Cadence- I really like the name. My least favorite is Cadence because it sounds kind of like a boy name Kaden. It is soo origional. I really like it.
Thomas Leo- Cute but there is no third name. I ADORE the name but i like Leo best as a nick name. So I would go either Thomas Leonardo Brayden or Leonardo Brayden Thomas. Or you could add your boyfriends name. That could be soo sentimental!!
Danvor Brayden Maxwell- Honestly, not my favorite. I think Danvor isn't very cute. I think it is too out there and it doesn't flow. Sorry!!
Laurent Joshua Jaden- LOVE joshua and Jaden, but not together. I think Laurent sounds like Lauren or Laurette. It is girly, to be brutely honest! I thinke Joshua Laurent Maxwell would be nice, but not Laurent first and no Joshua and Jaden in the same name. Josuha Brayden Laurent(if you absolutly adore Laurent) 
Hunter Wyatt Cruz- I like it. It isn't my favorite name, but it flows and sounds nice. I think Hunter is a weird, but everyone is entitled to their own opinion, and if you like it then it sounds nice.
Jasper Reed Gael- Don't like it. LOVE Reed, but Jasper is a ghost and Gael honestly sounds like Gay. I think Reed is a keeper and make it first if you are stuck on the other two. Like Reed Gael Jasper. But I like Reed Thomas Leodardo, Reed Hunter Joshua, Reed Joshua Cruz.



Hope this helped!!



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Thanks!



</asker's comment>

<answer>



girls;
Ivy Maya Renee - cute! I like it :) And different but not wierd
Rinnan Naomi Anne - I don't like Rinnan, but I love Naomi and Ann
Elisaveta Sanya Kate(Elisaveta and Sanya are both Bosnian..and my boyfriend is half Bosnian) - Elisaveta is interesting and very pretty. I like Sanya, but I don't think Kate flows too well

Esme Annabella Cadence - Don't really like Esme; Annabella is a little long; Cadence is cute

boys;
Thomas Leo(my boyfriend's father's name, and my boyfriend's grandfather) - love it :)
Danvor Brayden Maxwell - don't like Danver
Laurent Joshua Jaden - don't care for Laurent
Hunter Wyatt Cruz - I like Hunter and Wyatt, not Cruz. I think using Hunter and Wyatt together sounds a little cowboy-ish. Better if they are used with other names :)
Jasper Reed Gael - don't like Jasper, but I like the two middle names.

<answer from>



rubybenu...
Member since: 12 May 2008
Total points: 4602 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



My first thought was that mom is a poor speller or illiterate. It just looks ignorant.

So many people choose names by sound and don't take the time to find out how to spell them so they come up with a phonetic spelling, like Antwan, AntJuan, Antwon for Antoine.

My 2nd thought is that mom is looking for "unique" and "different" but doing it at the child's expense. She'll spend her life explaining the pronunciation and/or spelling of her name. There is a major possiblilty that school/government records will get messed up when a clerk makes a typo due to the odd spelling.

Not running with the herd or being different is good. I could really live without another krazy "K" name. I just think you should reconsider being different with the name since it can adversely affect this child for life.



Be different with the nn or with lifestyle or hobbies. Please be sensible with the name.



</answer>



<answer from>



Nikki
Member since: 22 May 2008
Total points: 1850 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>

</answer>

<answer>



I prefer classic, old-fashioned names too. I can give you a few suggestions (some names you will find among the top 100 lists of recent years purely due to resurgence in old-fashioned and classic names). See if you like any and feel free to come up with some first and middle name combinations if you wish. I realise some of these names can be made into modern nicknames, but almost any name can, all it truly takes it someone with imagination who wants something a little unique or different:

Elizabeth
Charlotte
Ava
Grace
Paige
Georgia
Gabrielle
Louise / Louisa
Isabelle / Isabel / Isobel
Lucinda
Hannah
Faith
Mary
Emily
Katherine / Kathryn
Victoria
Imogen
Chelsea
Ebony
Freya
Claudia
Ella
Paris
Bethany
Ruby
Rose
Sophia
Eliza
Molly
Abigail
Anna OR Annabelle
Matilda
Scarlett / Scarlette
Stella
Amy
Sara / Sarah
Eve / Evie
Layla
Amelia
Claire

All of these names, although most appear among the top 100 baby names lists over the past decade, originated many years ago, with most being common in 1800 - 1900 English and American society.

Best of luck with your quadruplets - all the best with your four precious miracles: may they bring you much happiness and joy.



</answer>

<category>

<question from>



Due 10/18 with Baby Girl #1!
Member since: 05 May 2008
Total points: 4686 (Level 4)



Contributing In:



Pregnancy



</question from>



<question>



Which middle name do you think sounds better?



We're having a baby girl next month and I'm debating about her middle name.  Originally we decided to go with Aria (pronounced R-e-uh) Elise, but lately, I'm thinking about Aria Michelle instead.  Elise is after my sister and Michelle is my middle name.  I think Michelle sounds better... what do you think?



Please, no other suggestions.  Thanks. :)



</question>



<answer from>



Amlie♥2nd Account♥
Member since: 16 May 2008
Total points: 6423 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Personally, I think honoring others by giving their first/middle name to your child is really nice. Is this your first child? If so, it would make sense if you name her after you.



I think Aria Michelle does sound better. I would just be sure your sister doesn't feel offended..if you told her about changing the middle name :)
Although you don't want another suggestion, just saying that Aria Elise-Michelle (with or without the hyphen) sounds beautiful!

Congrats!
xx



Source(s):



Aria is very unique & pretty :)



</answer>

<question>



Black & White names?!?!?



okay so i over heard a few ladies having a conversation and i remember them saying something about certain names are either Black or White! like for example: Mia is apparently a "white" name, and a name like Rashawn is a so called "black" name!
my Question is, when you named your child did you follow this rule of black/white name?
and does it even exist and fo you think its stupid?

hope this makes sense!!!!! lol



</question>



<additional details>



by asking this question i am not trying to be racist, i just thought it was silly that ppl can be so stupid about little thing like this.....and yes i know a name is a name regardless of its origin!



thanx so much!



</additional details>



<answer from>



y0_y0_20...
Member since: 14 November 2006
Total points: 752 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Its stupid - but true? despite what you want to believe. I'm white - I live in Detroit. I work and am friends with mostly all blacks, though this all doesn't matter.

There are definitely some 'black' names that you hear it and say 'they are black'. I know Jawana, Shamara, Laquisha, Yolanda, Jamal, Tyrell, etc. all have these feel.

I won't lie when I have kids I wouldn't name then Laquisha and Jamal or something unless the mom was black and it was important for her. I'm Irish/German, so my kids names will more then likely have something with a Irish/Germanic origin..

I hope you don't get a bunch of replies saying that your racist or the 'black names' are racist... But how many white kids walk around with the name Algeria, or Ebony, or something like that...

Same thing goes for Asians.. I've never met a white kid with the name Lu or Won...



Source(s):



Personal.



</answer>

thanks for your answer, i think you pretty much summed it up perfectly! cheers

<answer>



I think it's stupid. If people want to name their kids a name that wouldn't typically be seen on a person of their race, they should go ahead. Yes, some names do sound like they would be found on an African American, like Laquisha (just a stereotypical example), and there are names that sound like they would be a white person, but that doens't mean that they're specifically black or white names. I know tons of black and white girls that have the same names. There's an African American girl in my school named Julia, which is my name, and I don't think anything of it. Her parents liked the name Julia, hence she is Julia. If my parents loved the name Laquisha, I'm sure I would be Laquisha. Names are named, they're not assigned a race.



</answer>



<answer from>



Mommy's Having Triplets
Member since: 16 December 2007
Total points: 4161 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



I think that what you're talking about is thought about when making the choice of a name for your child, but I think it's done unconsciously. I don't think we know that we are thinking about that.



I know a couple women of color named Mia, but I don't know any women with a "black name". I think that is a horrible thing to say! Black names and White names... it just makes me sick. I don't care how many people say that racism doesn't exist anymore. It does and I am sick of hearing about it! African Americans and Americans are the same people! We're all human!!! Just because we have different skin color and we may talk differently doesn't mean that we are different. People from the south talk differently from us up here in the North! (I'm talking about United States just to clear that up.)

Names have origins, but I doesn't mean that they have to stay within that country!!!



</answer>

<question from>



Marisa
Member since: 31 August 2008
Total points: 177 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



What name do you really like out of all  these names?



Mila Angelique

Bella Angelique

Mia Angelique

Natasha Angelique

Natalia Angelique



If I have a kid in the future, I would really love to have a girl. I really love all the names, but I love Mila and Bella the most. Angelique would be the middle name. I hope to god I don't have a little boy. I love baby boys, but I always think of having a little baby girl. But if I don't have any kids, Thats also fine. But if I do - when I'm in my 20's, that it's only one baby and she's a beautiful baby girl.



</question>



<answer from>



Cristina ♥wishing for baby♥
Member since: 02 March 2008
Total points: 6119 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Mia Angelique. I have a friend that was going to name her baby girl Mia-Anyelik but then changed her mind.



BTW there are plenty of women out there (me included) that would give anything for a baby of either sex. Saying that you hope to God you don't have a baby boy is horrible! I you feel that way I hope you never have any kids.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Well thank you for hoping I never have kids. If I don't, I whould care less. I can live without a child. I'm not waiting for a baby anytime soon. I'm only 14. I never said that if it was a boy I would hate it. I just always thought of having a beautiful girl. I would still love a babyboy the same.



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



Stephi sayz BOO!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
Member since: 06 September 2008
Total points: 731 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I like Bella Angelique and Natasha Angelique!!!!!!!!!!!



</answer>



<answer from>



Monk Fan
Member since: 09 February 2008
Total points: 5141 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



Most people change their minds a hundred times before coming up with baby names. Why not wait until you find out that you ARE pregnant, know whether you're having a boy or girl, choose a name with the father, and let it be something fun to do during pregnancy?

I really don't like the name Angelique. But I like the names Mila and Natasha.



</answer>



<answer from>



make me famous.

<question from>



elsie's mummy, expecting #2
Member since: 25 March 2008
Total points: 2375 (Level 3)



</question from>



<question>



The boy's name Blaise?



just out of interest - how is it pronounced? I guess like 'Blaze' but i'm not sure. I don't think I'd use it if it was pronounced Blaze bc it would sound too modern and made up. Just wondering if there was some cool French pronunciation for it or something...anyone know?



</question>



<additional details>



yeah i'm not considering this name - just interested bc i couldn't work out how it was pronounced.



</additional details>



<answer from>



Sedora
Member since: 03 July 2008
Total points: 4907 (Level 4)



Contributing In:



Baby Names



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



The French pronuciation is "blez", with a long æ sound, like in bear, pear, tear.

From the Roman name Blasius which meant "lisping" from Latin blaesus. A famous bearer was Blaise Pascal, a mathematician and philosopher from France.

eta: alright, give the correct answer thumbs down. wth...
I had French at school and also: http://www.behindthename.com/name/blaise



</answer>



<asker's comment>



thanks



</asker's comment>

<question>

I gave birth to my second baby  2 days ago. She has tan skin with green eyes. I need some help deciding for her name.

My sister has told me that Aubrielle Ann is a very nice name for the way my baby looks. I like it,but I was wondering what else I could think of.

There's Mariah Nicole.
Katherine Marie.
Casey Ann.
Louisa.
Alexis.

Care to share? :D

<answer from>



_x.Maera...

</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Abigail Marie.

I was going to be the name of my first born girl. But being as young as I was, had to get an abortion ((as much as it pained me)). When I dream about her, she has beautiful tanned skin and vivid green eyes. And her laugh is the most beautiful in the entire world.

I love this name, and have always wished someone would name a baby girl Abigail Marie. A baby girl with tanned skin and toxic green eyes.

Best wishes and congrats :]
Maerad



</answer>

<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Love love love

Ophelia
Astrid
Clementine
Coralie
Eloise
Catherine
Claire
Isla
Scarlett
Anastasia



Jaime, to me, is a boy's name.
Mary is too common.
Paisley is too cutesy. It won't age well.
Coco is another that's just too cutesy.
Indigo is a color.
Romey sounds like a nickname.
Adelais looks like the shoe company.



</answer>

<answer>



my fav 3 from your girls would be:
Layla Rose- Layla is on my favs list. Rose is beautiful.
Mara Jane- Mara is so pretty! it's uncommon and i think would be darling on a little girl. Jane is lovely, i prefer to spell it Jayne though.

Alyssa Hope- one of my very good friends has a little girl named Alyssa Grace. Hope is so cute!!



my fav 3 from your boys would be:
Callum Thomas- Callum is uncommon and very cute. Thomas is a very masculine traditional name i love it.

Jason Adam- i love J names for boys for some reason, so Jason is a fav. Adam i LOVE!

Joshua James- i usually dont like first and middle to start w/the same letter, but i LOVE J names for boys..and these two just flow so perfect together.



the ones i dont like:
Ava Grace- both names are lovely. however they are INSANELY common these days, and two commong names together is just over kill.

Hayden Marie- *sigh* okay here comes a VERY biased moment ((sorry)). When my husband and i sat down to name our last child, we chose to honor his great-grandfather, Hayden William Thomas Myers III. Hayden has been, and will ALWAYS be a masculine name to me. I will never ever, ever like it on a girl. my son is named Hayden Ronald, Hayden after GGdad, and Ronald after MY father. Marie is a common borning filler name. i dont like it. i do however love Maria.
i think a great alternative to Hayden Marie would be Harper Maria.

India Cheyenne- i absolutely ADORE the name India for a girl! I cannot STAND the name Cheyenne or any of it's other spellings. it's very "country" sounding where i am from. a bit trailer park chic, if you get my drift.

Autumn Skye- i like the name Autumn and Skye is alright, but taken that your other daughter's name is Summer Rae it just sounds a bit corny to me.

Bryon Jack- first i dont like Bryon spelled that way i prefer Brian. Jack looks incomplete. i prefer Jackson. Brian Jackson looks nice.

Xavier Michael- Xavier is an adorable name, but you've paried it with an over used common, boring filler name. much like Matthew, Andrew, Scott, John,  and Lee.

Killian Sean- Not liking Killian at all. Sean i love.
congrats!!



Source(s):



Obsessed with baby names & Mother of 4, 12 y/o son, 10 y/o son, 2 y/o daughter and 11 month old son.



</answer>

<answer>



Ava Grace - 1/10
I'm not a fan of the trendy and popular Ava. I love Grace, but for a middle name it is just too common.

Alyssa Hope - 5/10
I prefer Alissa. Hope is okay.

Layla Rose - 3/10
I'm not big on Layla, it sort of sounds like white trash to me. Rose is filler as a middle, but gorgeous and underused as a first.

Hayden Marie - 0/10
Hayden is masculine and horrid on a little girl. Marie is filler, dull, common, and overused as a middle name.

India Cheyenne - 0/10
India is a country, not a name. Cheyenne just sounds like a hillbilly to me.

Mara Jane - 7/10
Mara is nice. Jane is gorgeous.

Autumn Skye - 0/10
Autumn is best left a season. Skye is masculine and a nickname.

Joshua James - 6/10
I love both names, but together they do not flow well.

Bryon Jack - 4/10
Bryon is misspelled, and I'm just not very fond of the name. Jack is excellent!

Jason Adam - 7/10
Jason is nice. Adam is okay. The names don't flow too well.

Xavier Michael - 4/10
Don't care for Xavier. Michael is filler.

Charlie Jon - 2/10
Charlie is a nickname. Charles John would be much, much, much better.

Callum Thomas - 2/10
I don't like Callum. Thomas is cute.

Killian Sean - 8/10
I love Cillian, but only when spelled with a 'C'. Also love Sean.



Cillian Sean and Mara Jane are your best bets.



</answer>

<answer>

<answer from>



Sandy
Member since: 11 December 2006
Total points: 303 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Pronunciation: Joo-lee-ah-na

I like it a lot. It's hard to find names these days that sound unique but at the same time aren't so far out into extraordinary that you'd be afraid to name you kid it. It has a beautiful ring to it and it's neither difficult to pronounce or spell. I think it has a quality of elegance to it.

Some facts, Julianna is a name of early Latin origin meaning 'youthful' or 'Jove's child'. It's considered a name of royalty in the Netherlands and there is more than one way of spelling it without losing the traditionalism:

Juliana, Juliane, Juliann, Julianne, Julieann, Julieanna and Julieanne.

I hope this helped you out a little bit.



Source(s):



I love looking up things about names for characters in my stories.



</answer>

<question>

Logan is my all time favourite boys name and I was just wondering what middle name you would put with it.



It doesn't matter if you don't like the name. There's no need to diss it or be mean. If you feel that your going to be mean then don't bother answering.



Also NO THUMBS DOWN!!! (unless the answer is obviously very stupid) I had to type that in capitals so I could get your attention.
And don't suggest it as a girls name because it's set as a boys name and you'll just be wasting your time.



Thanks



</question>

<question>



What name would you put with this name?



To set things straight, I'm NOT pregnant. I live in England so what's popular in America might be different in England.



What boys middle name would you put with Zachary?



So it would be Zachary .........?



It doesn't matter if you don't like the name. There's no need to diss it or be mean. If you feel that your going to be mean then don't bother answering.



Also NO THUMBS DOWN!!! (unless the answer is obviously very stupid) I had to type that in capitals so I could get your attention.



Names that can't be used are Phillip, Don, Alan, Paul, Keith, Christopher, Christian, Connor, Matthew, Daniel, Robert, Kelvin, Doug, Cole, Ross cause they are names of the guys in my family



Another name that can't be used is Steven as that's my boyfriends dads name.



Thanks



</question>



<additional details>



I take it someone doesn't understand what NO THUMBS DOWN means!!!!



Allen is the same as Alan and that name can't be used as it's my cousins name.



I understand that people like different names but I just don't like people getting thumbs down. It's a matter of opinion and what people like. I hardly ever give thumbs down unless they are rude and mean or the answer is just plain stupid.

<question>



What do you think of the girl name...?



Béibhinn

http://www.behindthename.com/name/be10bh...



</additional details>



<answer from>



MW&M- I ♥ Halloween
Member since: 22 January 2007
Total points: 35167 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Dogs



Baby Names

<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



It's not my cup of tea. im not fond of girl names that start with the "Bay" sound like:



Bailey, Baden, Baila, etc.



but im mad about the spelling! lol i love traditional spellings. it ads a sense of class and uniqueness to it that you would lose if you gave it a trendy, fruity spelling like Bayvin or Bayvyn or Baevan or something crazy like that. lol



Source(s):



Obsessed w/baby names & mother to 4 great kids- 12 y/o son, 10 y/o son, 2 y/o daughter & 1 y/o son.



</answer>

<question>



Aubrey Jasper Lane or Aubrey Greer Jude?



Which do you prefer for a little boy?



Aubrey Jasper Lane
Aubrey Greer Jude



Aubrey, Lane, and Greer are all masculine boy's name. So don't bother posting that they are girl's names or they are feminine.



</question>



<additional details>



I like Lane as a first name too, but Lane Aubrey Jude doesn't really have a good flow.



Wrong, Lane is a male's name.



Greer is from Gregor which is from Gregory. I'd say that's pretty much a masculine boy's name and so is Greer.



These are proper boy names.



Thank you Katherine!



</additional details>

<answer from>



lucyQ
Member since: 22 October 2008
Total points: 138 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



I agree with the majority who say they don't like the name Rhianna. Maybe it's due to the pop-star; maybe I just don't care for it!



If you like the "anna" names, you might consider Annabelle, Annabella, or Annalaura. Also, Annalisa, which is spelled a host of different ways.



I would advocate you keep the name Madison and make it her middle name - that way you can call your girls by different names, but they both get to use it. If she came to you with a middle name, you might consider just flipping the order of her two names.



If you're looking for other names that go with Madison, you might also consider a theme... such as naming your newest daughter after a different locale that doubles as a girl's name (Sydney, Georgia, Florence, London, Savannah, etc.)



</answer>

<answer>



My favorite is Amaya... it's a beautiful Japanese name meaning "night rain" and a Spanish/Basque name deriving from the name of a mountain range.  It's uncommon, but it's unmistakably feminine, and it feels very multicultural.



Most of your other choices strike me as a bit more trendy or made up.  It think Paige is okay, but it's slightly more run-of-the-mill.

<question>



Baby boy/girl name question?



What are some names you like for a boy but you like less for a girl or vice versa?



I like Noah for a girl, but not so much for a boy.



I like Paulina for a boy, but do not like Paul for a boy at all.
I prefer name Devan for a girl over name Devin for a boy.
I like Bobbie for a girl, but not so much for a boy.
I prefer Regan/Reagan for a boy and less for a girl
I like Rudy for a boy, not a girl
I prefer Taylor for a boy over a girl
Those are just some and I have found that my trend is to really like the names that are LESS common for one sex, how about yourself?



</question>



<additional details>



So I am guessing the rest is crazy because you did NOT hear of the others names attached to the preferred sex?  I was wondering if you could follow the actual question which was, do you find this to be the case for yourself not with MY names but names of your own, I think you will find we all do for certain names and I was hoping you would share THOSE names



</additional details>



<answer from>



ILY M.K.M
Member since: 22 October 2006
Total points: 2240 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



yo, are you serious? your children will hate you.



i do know a girl named Devin but the rest is crazy



</answer>



<answer from>



Emmy Jo
Member since: 06 July 2007
Total points: 13030 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Baby Names



</answer from>



<answer>



I love Ashley for a boy; I find it extremely boring on a girl.  If a name seems trendy on one gender but classic on another, I usually prefer it on the more classic-sounding gender.



Note:  I would never actually use Ashley on a boy, as I know it could lead to merciless teasing, but still I love it.



I completely agree with you that Taylor is much better on a boy!



I actually prefer Regan on a girl, though.  On a girl, it seems Shakespearean.  On a boy, it feels like part of the "surnames as first names" trend.



</answer>



<answer from>



Kogy
Member since: 01 April 2008
Total points: 336 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>

I don't really like Paulina, Bobbie, Regan, or Rudy, but I do like Noa, Devan and Taylor.



</answer>

<question>



Opinions and suggestions on baby names?



I have thought up some names for my future children and I wanted some opinions, and some suggestions for names.. I like more unusual names, so these are my taste a bit. =]
Please give your opinion of all names. Will choose a best answer. =]



For girls:
Eliana Marie; [Ell-ee-awna]
Arielle Isabella; [Ar-ee-ell]
Annaleigh Rose; [Aww-na-lee]
Ariya Elizabeth; [Arr-ee-ya]
Lillian Annabella.



For boys:
Uriah Mackai [You-rhy-uh] [Muh-ky]
Brayden Samuel;
Preston James;
Aohdan Matthew. [A-oh-den]



Thank you guys for your opinions and suggestions!



</question>



<answer from>



Ray (Obama '08)
Member since: 09 July 2008
Total points: 4106 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



-Eliana Marie; This is a beautiful name! Love it
-Arielle Isabella; The endings are really similar... Say it out loud. I dunno, it's pretty, but maybe a different middle name? Arielle Lillian would be better.
-Annaleigh Rose; Annaleigh is a gorgeous name! Great choice
-Ariya Elizabeth; Not crazy about Ariya. And I don't like the double vowels. Ha ha sorry I'm picky
-Lillian Annabella; It's kinda a mouthful. Maybe Lillian Annabel instead?



-Suggestions-
Elliot Rose, Kennedy Jayne, Remington Alexandra, Delaney Lauren Grace, Leah Juliet



-Uriah Mackai; Sorry, not crazy about either name.
-Brayden Samuel; This is good! I like this one. I know everyone hates the "Aidan" trend, but whatever.
-Preston James; I like this one too! Another good choice
-Aohdan Matthew; Eh... How about Aidan instead?



-Suggestions-
Aidan Lucas, Cameron Alexander, Jack Austin, Joel Anderson, Nathan Thomas



</answer>

<question from>

Contributing In:



Baby Names



</question from>



<question>



Opinions on these names- Please =]?



What do you think of these names?



Corrina Gabrielle Cash- girl



Connor Joseph Cash- boy



I don't mind the double C's ( for those that hate that )
Just curious as to what others think!



;]meg



</question>



<answer from>



vickiema...
Member since: 08 August 2008
Total points: 4447 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



I like them, Actually kind of Original. At least I have only known 1 Corrina & 1 Conner personally in my life time, & I am 50, & worked in a Assembly plant with over 5000 people, & attended a University , so I have been exposed to all kinds of Names of people! Good Choice's



</answer>



<asker's comment>



thanks =]



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



balladof...
Member since: 07 July 2008
Total points: 2785 (Level 4)



Contributing In:



Baby Names



</answer from>



<answer>



Corrina Gabrielle: I don't like the sound of the first name, I think that Gabrielle is a great middle name and that the balance of syllables overall is ideal but Corrina doesn't do much for me. It seems childish and I don't feel its very becoming.



Connor Joseph: I love the fluidity of this name, Connor is very cute for a boy and Joseph, being more traditional is very complimenting, once again the balance of syllables is nice and adds to the overall appeal. I also like, Connor Michael and Connor James.



If you really like names that start with 'C' for a girl try:



Charlotte
Chelsea
Charity
Camille
Clarissa



</answer>



<answer from>



Gabbi
Member since: 19 October 2008
Total points: 122 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>

<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Girls:
Leah Nichole- Cute but un-original.

Bridget Ainslinn- Very cute! How would you pronounce the middle name though?



Boys:



Luke Patrick- I like this but personally think Patrick Luke sounds better.
Eli Nikolas- oh my gosh that is an awesome name I love it!
Mitchel James- Like Luke Patrick I think it might sound better flipped around.



Blake Carlin- Blake is my all time favorite name and I like how a really common name is paired up with a unique middle name!

<answer>



Not a fan of either. The first name might be mistaken for the "ow" sound, and be pronounced "Ow-Den", and then it will sound similar to the Audi.



Avonlea is okay, but I just don't like it in general. I guess she could go by Lea but a whole it's not a very nice name.



When both children are older they're bound to get picked on because of their names, which means that they're bound to hate you for life.



Also I thought that Auden was a boys name not a girls.



Think of something pretty, unique but not something so unique that people are gonna be like what?



Just some advice and I hope it helps



Earthy



</answer>

<answer>



My grandparents were very Catholic as well.



They named their kids Elizabeth, Ann, Daniel, Carl, Edward, Mary, and John.



Big family.



You could also consider names like Joseph, Katherine, Michael, James, Matthew.  Really anything that won't get in the way of baptismal rights.  For example, stay away from names like Darwin.  (my grandmother wanted to name my uncle Daniel, Darwin, but the priest wouldn't baptize him Darwin, so she had to switch).



</answer>

<question>



What do you think of the name Ira?



It's pronounced "eye-rah" and it's for a boy.



</question>

<answer from>



LYNN IN FL
Member since: 08 December 2007
Total points: 9335 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Ira is a BOYS name!! I have never seen a woman named Ira, maybe Iris for a female but not Ira. Where do people come up with its a girls name? It is a Jewish name and also a name used commonly a hundred years ago. For boys. It means watchful.



If you like Ira, use it. There won't been 10 of them in every class.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Thanks guys!



Lynn, you hit the name on the head! Btw, It isn't only my little brother's, it was also my great-grandfathers (born in 1880s!); pretty old name! :)



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



Twlight....
Member since: 22 July 2007
Total points: 3120 (Level 4)



Contributing In:

</answer from>



<answer>



Personally, I like it - but it is not my style...



I think it is a perfect name for today's society - easily pronounced and spelled, yet different (without really being unknown). I think many of the child's contemporaries will think it something totally unique and therefore "cool'... but 1-3 generations older and people will still like the name for being a classic :-)



HTH :-)



</answer>

<question from>



tsar
Member since: 05 August 2008
Total points: 363 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



Is Rauf a good name for a boy ?



Do you know what it means? origin ...



</question>



<answer from>



justlike...
Member since: 26 May 2006
Total points: 4 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Sounds too much like "ruff"



</answer>



<answer from>



Mimi
Member since: 27 December 2007
Total points: 2209 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Sorry! I think of a dog with this name..but Rauf means Servant of compassionate.



Source(s):



http://www.baby-names-meanings.net/meani...



</answer>



<answer from>



Vr
Member since: 25 March 2008
Total points: 6254 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



Origin:



Arabic



Meaning:



Merciful; compassionate



Pronunciation:



(rah OOF)



Source(s):



http://babynamesworld.parentsconnect.com...



</answer>

<answer>

<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



I believe the first responder had it about right: ooh...Heidi! The name Emily is just far too common. Not only that, but the name Heidi is so much better - it's cute! When I say the name Heidi aloud, I think of an adorable little girl with pigtails. :^]



Source(s):



http://babynamesworld.com



http://babynames.com



I almost always give these websites out. I hope I assisted you. Take care.



</answer>

no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>

<answer>



Carly Elizabeth



I think it's great. It gives you a short, fun call name and a traditional, regal middle name. Since I don't know what your last name is, I suggest you try out the initials to be sure it's still ok.



Congratulations. When she gets here I think you'll see that a little girl is EXACTLY what you wanted.

<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



Alicia Mae - 10/10. Aw this name is gorgeous and it flows really well with your surname.



Becky Jade - 9/10. Again beautiful but I think, if you go for this one, it should be Rebekah/Rebecca Jade and Becky as her nickname.



Carly Elizabeth - 8/10. Not a major fan of the name Carly - I prefer Carla - but it flows well with Elizabeth and is not a name that is seen/used very often.



Faye Louise - 7/10. Both names are favourites of mine, but I just don't think they go together well - it's like there is a name missing in it. E.g. Faye Louise Mae Blake.



Hannah Anne - 7/10. Love these names but their awfully common. Plus there is too much "Anne" in it.



Imogen Rose - 8/10. I really like it. It's gorgeous.



Lacey Jane - 6/10. It's alright but I don't think Lacey is the best name for a little girl.



Molly Mae - 7/10. Love both the names, and they flow well, I just don't like names which go "M-M" or "E-E" (so they begin with the same letter in other words). It's not bad though, has a nice ring to it.



Natasha Jade - 9/10. Beautiful. Flows really well.



Olivia Jane - 9/10. I love this name, and I've got it down in my Top 10 namelist for a little girl, but, instead of it being first they're both middles. I really like the Nerea Olivia Jane (Nuh-Ray-Uh/ Ner-Ay-A - whichever is easier to undestand where prononciation is concerned.)



Rachael Anne - 6/10. I love both names just together.



Sophie Marie - 8/10. Pretty but I think Sophia Marie Blake sounds better. Sophie Marie has to many "E" endings.



Tessa Jane - 4/10. I love the name Jane, just not a big fan of the name Tessa. Sorry. Doesn't flow that well either.



Yasmin Mae - 6/10. I love both the names I just don't think they go that well with the surname.



Lauren Jane - 7/10. Both names are nice and flow well, but there is a girl that I know called Lauren and she's a little gobby cow and I can't stand her. I like the name, but I just don't like association with that name.



Madeleine Mae - 8/10. Again it's the same letter thing but I quite like this one. It's pretty, and flows well with the surname.



Lily Anne - 7/10. If said really fast it sounds like Lillian. Both pretty names, that flow well together, but it's not my favourite.



Kelly Anne - 5/10. Not a big fan of the name Kelly, but it does flow well.



Lucy Rose - 7/10. It's alright but it just doesn't work for me.



Kelsey Jane - 8/10. Interesting and unique as well as beautiful. I really like it. It flows well with the surname.



Victoria Marie - 9/10. I love the first name (after all, it's my name) and it goes well with the middle name too. How about Victoria Rose or Victoria Helen as other ideas (they're my middle names - Victoria Rose Helen - so maybe I'm a bit biased) they go well with the last name really well too.



Melissa Jane - 9/10. I love it! Enough said.



Overall my favourites are:



Alicia Mae Blake



Rebecca (Becky) Jade Blake
Carly/Carla Elizabeth Blake
Imogen Rose Blake
Natasha Jade Blake



Olivia Jane Blake
Sophie/Sophia Marie Blake
Madeleine Mae Blake
Kelsey Jane Blake
Victoria Marie
Melissa Jane



But my ultimate favourite is Alicia Mae - it's just gorgeous!



Hope this helps



Earthy



</answer>

no answerer details

<answer>



Alicia Mae: I love Alicia but I prefer it with Jane or Jade.



Becky Jade: I don't really like the name Becky, Jade is a decent middle name.



Carly Elizabeth: Great Choice! The two names compliment each other well.



Faye Louise: Don't care for either. Sorry.



Hannah Anne: They sound too alike Hannah has Anne in it already. Try Hannah Jane, Jade, Rose, Grace, or Elise



Imogen Rose: I don't like Imogen, it seems dated, Rose is a cute middle name.



Lacey Jane: I prefer Gracie, Jane is a cute middle name.



Molly Mae: If you want a double M I think Molly Marie sounds better but Molly Mae is cute too.



Natasha Jade: Not my top pick of your names but cute.



Olivia Jane: Cute name.



Rachael Anne: Cute combination but not my favorite.



Sophie Marie: I like this one too, Sophie Rose is cute as well.



Tessa Jane: Not a huge fan but its different.



Yasmin Mae: Don't really like this one. Sorry. It just doesn't sound right to me.



Alicia Mae: 7/10
Becky Jade: 4/10
Carly Elizabeth: 9/10
Faye Louise: 3/10
Hannah Anne: 4/10 With a different middle name 8/10
Imogen Rose 3/10
Lacey Jane: 4/10 Gracie Jane 6/10
Molly Mae: 6/10
Natasha Jade: 6/10
Rachael Anne: 7/10
Sophie Marie: 8/10
Tessa Jane: 5/10
Yasmin(e) Mae: 3/10

<answer from>



kittysue...
Member since: 09 March 2007
Total points: 3450 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Your girls will already have their last name in common so you don't NEED to give them the same middle name. But it may be something really special to you or a family tradition which is nice. Also, very few people will ever know your child's middle name so most of their friends won't know the two girls have the same middle name.



On my dad's side of the family it has been a tradition for generations that the sons receive the father's first name as a middle name. I only have one brother so it wasn't a problem, but my uncle had 4 boys and all have Henry (his first name) as their middle name.



Anastasia Louise
Mathilda Louise
Catherine Louise
Amanda Louise
Marina Louise



</answer>

<question>

Aaralyn



It's pronounced like Carolyn but without the "C". I really like but I was wondering what you thought of it?

Earthy



PS: Don't ask about the spelling that is how it's spelt according to babynames.com



PPS: 8 weeks to go until baby girl is born! So excited!



</question>



<additional details>



It was a choice but my boyfriend didn't like it, which is a shame because I think it's such a beautiful name. My favourite combination (even though the middle is considered a filler middle name) is Aaralyn Rose. It just seems to flow!



No it's not Welsh, it's American. I think it's a created name - but a pretty one at that - but I personally think it should mean "beautiful".



No I didn't mean to put a C instead of an A. This is an actual name. Check it on babynames.com if you don't believe me.

<answer>



Unique is always good in my book, unless it's to the point of getting picked on. (I grew up next to Pebbles and Bambi).
My name is Heather and I was born in 1980, around the time that Heather was the #1 name in the country. I grew up in a class of 94--4 of which were named Heather. In marching band in college, there were 5 other Heathers. And in the agency where I work, there are 7 Heathers is high up positions (The rest are uncountable). Although my name is pretty, I grew up hating it because I didn't even have a nickname to try and differentiate me from the others. When I name my kids, I'm picking rare names. Gideon, Cecilee, Aryah, Thorsten... Different is better. (You don't need one of those little license plates with your name on it anyway.)



</answer>



<answer from>

You just hear:  Marie, Astrid, Donovan, Kayden, Alexandria, and Hayley.  Names you would hear anywhere.  The only problem with unique spelling is that the child is doomed to be forever spelling his/her name or correcting people on the pronunciation.  My youngest daughter is Brynn and it's amazing how many people struggle to pronounce it when they see it on paper.  Most people think it's a misprint and say Bryan.  :(
