<question from>



Dorian
Member since: 25 September 2008
Total points: 2407 (Level 3)



Contributing In:



Baby Names



</question from>



<question>



What naming trends do you hate / love?



There seems to be a lot of different trends today with naming babies.  Anyone who's seen my questions knows I love masculine names for girls - and I know some absolutely hate this.



Personally, I hate the trend of misspelling a name to make it "creative."  I think it just looks tacky and like the parents couldn't spell.  (And to each their own - I know some parents love to do this.)



So I'm curious, what are the trends that you absolutely love or hate???



</question>



<answer from>



Jamie
Member since: 25 December 2005
Total points: 2432 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



I, too, am a fan of the old fashioned names coming back into style. It just bugs me that I see SO MANY little girls with the same name. It kind of ruins the name for me. This happened with Abigail, then Olivia, then Emma, and now Sophia. They are such pretty names, but they aren't so pretty when every parent gives them to a girl. There are still a few that aren't too overused that I love to see on little girls: Audrey, Lydia, Eleanor, Charlotte, Sylvia, etc.



I also like the Biblical names for boys trend. Now, we not only have little Jacobs, but Elijahs, Gabriels, Calebs, even Seths. I don't just say this because I'm a Christian, but I do think the Bible is one of the best places to find names, especially the Old Testament. The Hebrews gave their kids some cool names (well, with a few exceptions, like Benjamin's sons: Muppim, Huppim, and Ard :D).



Sorry to say it, but I really don't like seeing boys' names on little girls. For one, girls are girls and boys are boys. You wouldn't name a boy Emily or Sarah, would you? Yet for whatever reason people think it's cute to name give their girls masculine names, like Alexis and Ryan. There are a few I can stand: Alex and Sam are nicknames that work for either gender, and Meredith and Harper are two traditionally masculine names that a boy would get beat up for having on the playground today and work better on girls.



I like surnames on boys (unless they're really ridiculous, like Zobalewski), but not on girls. Some surnames are tolerable for first names (like if you wish to honor someone, like Harper Lee, President Reagan, or your best friend, Joe Delaney), but usually seeing a little girl with a surname for a first name makes me crinkle my nose, Madison being my main pet peeve. But what bugs me even more is one of the fastest rising girls names last year: Addison. So you want to call your daughter Addy. How nice. Then name her Adele, Adina, or Aderyn. Do not give her a name that not only means "son of Adam", but is also the name of a disease.



I don't like kreeyative spehllyngs either. Naming your daughter Kaetelynne is not going to make her stand out from all the other Caitlins, Kaitlyns, and Katelyns in her class. It just makes you look silly and uneducated.



And I really don't like the -adens. Aidan, Brayden, Caden, Jayden, Kayden, Zaydon (yes, I have actually met a little Zaydon), and who knows what else. Aidan was a nice Irish name before it skyrocketed it popularity so fast it tore it's face off, and now everyone's adding a new consanant to it in hopes of having their son "stand out". What's next? Fadin? Maiden?



Yeah, I think I covered it all. :D



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Obviously we disagree on masculine names for girls and I love surnames for girls too, but to each their own.  But I totally agre with you on the -adens names; I can't stand those.  And while I'm not very religious I agree that biblical names are wonderful.  Thanks for you input.



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



Robbin R
Member since: 15 August 2008
Total points: 450 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Masculine names for girls is a cute trend-until the girls get older and apply for jobs-when they call for ' Taylor' or 'Morgan' or 'Kyle' Smith by saying 'Mr. Smith'- its going to be confusing or when she's older, she'll be called "Grandma Kyle"! Its like when men have the names of Leslie or Marion or Hillary or Kim-youre looking around for a woman. I dont like my name Robbin (its also my mom's & sister's middle name and I have a cousin named Robyn) but I hate it misspelled even more. There's an actress whose name is Khrystyna (Christina). The 'new' trend is the 'old' names-- Rose, Victoria, Maxwell, Samuel, Emma, and Jacob. Elizabeth is still the most common middle name. If a masculine name is important (named after a relative), 'female-ize' it or use it as a middle name.



</answer>



<answer from>



Jill
Member since: 21 August 2008
Total points: 298 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I read about this trend where parents get a new name by spelling a more traditional name backwards. For instance, Nevaeh for Heaven. I really like that and plan to use it for my first girl.



I hate it when people name their kids the same name as the parent. (Like John Lee Smith and John Lee Smith Junior) It's so annoying. My mom and dad did that and their son ruined their credit (He lived at the same address when he was grown and out on his own--my mom and dad had a LOT of property).



I disagree with you about the creative spelling of a name. I'm thinking about legally changing the spelling of my name because my name is too common anymore. I like the not-so-common names (i.e. Xi-Wang pronounced Chee Wong) and thus, can appreciate a unique spelling.



</answer>



<answer from>



Kelly
Member since: 05 June 2007
Total points: 2699 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



i agree w/ the misspellings.  i don't mind a slight change in the spelling (Kelly, Kelli, Kellie); however the ones that are ridiculous are annoying, or the ones that have a million ways of spelling it (aiden, aaden, ayden, aydyn, aeden, aedyn, aidyn, adyn, etc)



i don't like the "mc" names.  i think any of the "mc" names are trashy (just my opinion)
(ex Mckenzie, McKenna, McKayla, etc)



i Absolutely detest the name Neveah.



my personal opinion is that i don't like masculine names for girls.  there are some really cute unisex names (reagan, riley, taylor) but that is my opinion, and i respect yours.



i like names that have originality, but aren't crazy (Lorelai, kyler, rylan)



i also like seeing some of the more old fashioned names coming back (emily, elizabeth, henry, lillian)



</answer>

Besides it is still Catherine. I also hate when people spell a name one way and pronounce it another like Sean, Shawn. But you are right to each their own.

<answer>



Resurgence of old-fashioned names - love this.  It gives respect to history and your ancestors and sounds like you've worked, searched, and sifted to find the perfect name for your kid.



I also hate creative spellings.  To me, it looks like you wanted something unique, but were too lazy or uneducated to find something in the thousands of names in the millennia of history that suited your fancy.



</answer>

<question>



What do you think of these baby names?



Ok I'm going to be a single mommy. I'm black and my childs father is Russian. So tell me what you think

Boy Name: Jalen Dimitri Denischik...... or Jalen Dmirti Denischik



</question>

Also who cares if some one's asking how to spell it,if me and his/her father were to get back together you'd be saying give the child some random simple last name because some ppl cant just sound things out DENISCHIK is pronounced DEN-ISH-IK OMG just answer what you think of the baby names  not your opinion of how the last name will be confusing... thats beyond the point. Oh... and Im set on the names on the page and i'm not asking for additional names. Thanks to everyone who was positive! :-D

<question>



Opinions on these baby names please?



I'm still narrowing down my list so I'd appreciate your opinions on these names?  Why do you like them or not like them?  And yes, I know most of the girl names are masculine names - that's what I prefer.  I matched the first names with middle names I like but feel free to switch around (though the names I used for middle, I only like for middle names not first).  Last name will be Owens.  Thanks!!



Girls:



Cordelia Kiernan
Riley Fiona



Emerson Willa
Elliot Spencer
Spencer Jane
Holden Winifred



Ainsley Eleanor



Boys:



Jackson Alexander



Bradley Christopher
Spencer James
Julian Alexander
Quinton James



</question>



<additional details>



To the answer that said a girl with a masculine name will turn out masculine - that's ridiculus.  I have a masculine name and love it, it sounds so professional.  And I was never a tomboy, rather a frilly girl - still am.



</additional details>



<answer from>

Total points: 150 (Level 1)

<answer>



Cordelia Kiernan- It's not my absolute favorite name, I just don't really like the sound of it, but it's still a decent name!
Riley Fiona- I love Riley!  It is so cute!  Fiona not so much, but it's fine if it's just a middle name.
Emerson Willa- This is a very beautiful name!  I never considered Emerson as a girl's name, but it's very unique and pretty!
Elliot Spencer- I think this one's a little too masculine for me- but it's definitely your decision and you could have some cute nicknames like Elle if you wanted!
Spencer Jane- I'm sorry, the two names just don't go together for me.  But again, it's your choice!
Holden Winifred- Very interesting!  It's pretty...
Ainsley Eleanor- Very beautiful and elegant!  I like it a lot!



Jackson Alexander- I love the name Jackson!  Alexander compliments it nice as a middle name!
Bradley Christopher- Very nice name!  I love it!
Spencer James- Good, strong name.
Julian Alexander- I'm not a big fan of Julian, but it's not horrible!

<answer from>



aed-emer...
Member since: 14 December 2007
Total points: 1858 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



I really love Cordelia on a girl.  You said you prefer masculine names, and while Cordelia is a legitimate girls name, it is not all feminine and frills.  Plus, you have the option of Cory as a nickname.



I know you like less feminine names but in the long run, giving your daughter a name used only for boys-- like, Holden-- will cause a lot of confusion in life.  Everything will be addressed to Mr. __, everyone will assume she is a boy befor meeting her, etc.  Cordelia gives you the best of both worlds-- she has a masculine name to go by (Cory) but should she choose to want soemthing a bit less boyish, she has Cora, Delia, or the full name.



Just to mix and match a bit, Cordelia Kiernan has that repeating K sound and something like Cordelia Eleanor or Cordelia Fiona would flow much better.



I really like your boys names. Jackson Alexander and Julian Alexander are my favorites.



</answer>

<question>



What does my name mean?

x

<answer from>



K'Tumble
Member since: 29 April 2008

<answer>



It means 'from Hadria'.



:)



Source(s):



http://www.thinkbabynames.com/meaning/0/...



</answer>



<answer from>



ashley j
Member since: 11 August 2007
Total points: 9565 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



female form of Adrian; from the Adriatic Sea region; woman with dark features



Source(s):



"The complete book of baby names" by Lesley Bolton



</answer>



<answer from>



dancelov...
Member since: 05 October 2007
Total points: 143 (Level 1)

Dell

<answer>



Its source is Hadrianus, a Latin name meaning "One from the city of Adria, in northern Italy."



Source(s):



http://www.babynamer.com/Adriena



</answer>

<answer>



Adrienna, a 4-syllable girl's name of Latin origin, means: Dark; woman of the sea.



Was not able to find the name with 1 "N"

<answer>



it is "from hadria"

<answer from>



freiaxxx
Member since: 21 July 2008
Total points: 752 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Amelie- I love this name!! It is cute and timeless, elegant and classy, without becing wierd or hard to spell o r pronounce. I love it with the accent on the e as well. Great name!
Bellatrix- I love the name Bella, it is short and simple and cute but I don't really like it with the 'trix' ending. It isn't as easy to say although it is more unusual that other 'Bella' names, such as Isabella ( which I still love!). I think maybe you should choose from either Bella or Beatrix. However, Bellatrix is not a bad name!
Aasta- I think this is unusual and quirky and quite nice although I am personally not that keen on it.



Eva- Love this too! Ava is becoming incredibly popular now and this is just as nice but not as common. It is really pretty and classic, it is the name of Eva Ibbotson too, a great childrens' author.
Liv- Too nicknamey to be a complete first name, maybe you could choose a name that could have this as its nickname. Or you could have Vivienne and Viv as the nickname. I'm not thatkeen on Liv anyway.
Skye- Cute!! I prefer this as a middle name, Amelie Skye, gorgoeus!! It is nice for a first name though, I'm not sure about how it would suit an adult but I still really like it!
Annette- I really like this too! It is unusual and pretty, will suit a child without being too old-fashioned and is easy to spell and pronounce. i like the nicknames Etta or Ettie or Annie.
Faye- Short and pretty, not one of my favorites but still looks and sounds nice, kind of delicate, I think, what about Fleur? I think that is kind of nice.
Amalexia-sounds too much like Anorexia, I can see that the nicknames Lexie or Ammy could be good though.
Erin- Love this name! It is a poetic name for Ireland, and is really pretty and not overused. I like Esme too.
My favorite is Amelie, but Eva, Annette, Skye and Erin are good too. Hope this helps! x
Now I have seen the pronunciation, I really like Aasta too and Bellatrix is growing on me!



</answer>



<answer from>

Total points: 176 (Level 1)

<answer>



The Icelandic way of spelling the name is Ásta and I love the name. (Aasta does not exist in Iceland - there are no first names starting with "Aa" in the Statistics Iceland data base of all citizens)



If you like Icelandic names, others to consider are



Elín
Bryndís
Lilja
Erla

<answer>



Hannah Grace and Sarah Mia and Elizabeth Sophia are probably the best.  Any first name that ends with -y will sound too close to Emily and any middle name that ends with -n will sound too close to Madison.  Lisa Michelle is cute too, but I think if you use both names, the name will sound too old.



Hope I helped :)



</answer>

Cheryl A

<answer>



1. Jennifer Megan - No, there are way too many Jennifers and Megans in this world already



2. Lisa Michelle - Nice name, but a little boring



3. Susan Mary - too old fashioned and dowdy



4. Isabella Emma (Is Emma To Close To Emily?) I like both names but they don't flow well because of the vowel proximity



5. Ava Grace - sounds like praying



6. Elizabeth Sophia (Is Emily And Elizabeth To Rhymey?) - Nice name, and no, not too rhymey.  :)  But then, I have Robin and Rachel, so am not averse to aliteration



7. Hannah Grace - more praying.  Don't get me wrong.  I love the name Grace, just not in these pairings.



8. Sarah Mia - Flows well, sounds nice.  Why don't I like this?



9. Sophie Lauren - You're kidding, right?  Think ancient Italian movie star Sofiya Loren



10. Natalie Victoria - Lovely.  This is quite nice.



11. Sydeny Victoria - Also very nice



12. Paris Melissa - I like Paris (even though it's been tainted by its famous namesake), but I don't like the pairing with plain and humdrum Melissa.



13. Kelsey Jane - Well then, here we have two plain names that really spark when paired together.  I like this.



14. Alexis Lucy - Hmmm . . . I think I like Lucy Alexis better



15. Amber Jane - No.  Just No.  Have always hated the name Amber.  Sounds like a stripper.  Sorry.



</answer>

JD08L12

<answer>



My favorites are Hannah Grace and Amber Jane. They both flow really well (assuming it sounds good with your last name) and they both fit well with Emily. Ava and Sophie are too popular these days, so i would steer clear of those (unless you absolutely love them, then by all means go for it) and Paris is too trendy and in my opinion, a little trashy (sorry). I also like the name Natalie, but not the middle name you have chosen, mostly because i have never been a fan of 'v' names, and i am partial to Jennifer Megan just because my name is Jennifer. i love Elizabeth Sophia, but i do feel that it is too rhyme-y and Emma is definitely too close to Emily.  Congratulations on your second daughter, i wish you the best!



</answer>

<question>



Do you think this name is too long or sounds bad for a boys name?



My boyfriend and I have chosen names for our kids (when the time comes..hopefully not any time soon) and he has always wanted his son to be named exactly after him then I have always wanted to name my daughter what my mom wanted to name me (but my g-g-ma ended up naming me Ashley Nicole). So for the first boy we want Jacob Michael Jr., the first girl- Summer Nicole Lynn (does that sound ok..we couldnt agree on either nicole or lynn..so yea..) and for our second boy we both wanted to name him after our fathers. His fathers name is Kenneth and my fathers middle name is Edward (his first name is James)..so we thought that maybe Jason Edward Kenneth would sound okay..but idk. Do you think thats too much or does it go together okay? I would really enjoy hearing everybodys HONEST opinions on these names. Thank You!!

<answer from>



Brooke
Member since: 08 August 2008
Total points: 1468 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Personally, I'm not a fan of two middle names.  It makes names annoyingly long and no one even cares about middle names anyway.  Also, I'm not a fan of naming children exactly after the father.  Why limit yourself so much?  Maybe make the middle name be your boyfriend's name or choose your own middle name if you go with the same first name.



Jacob Michael is a nice name though.  I like it better than Jason Edward Kenneth.  Of all those names my favorite combination is Jacob Edward or James Michael.



I like Summer Nicole better than Summer Lynn because Summer Lynn sounds like one name when you say it.  Summer Nicole Lynn is okay if I liked two middle names.



Basically, all of the names you're working with are nice names.  Any combination you do will be a great name. :)



</answer>



<answer from>

Total points: 126 (Level 1)

<answer from>



Cheryl A
Member since: 18 June 2007
Total points: 3963 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Rachel - love this name and the classic spelling.  Loved it so much in fact that my second daughter is named Rachel.  :)



Alexa - pretty, but kind of common
Halle - love this a lot, but would not choose it because I wouldn't want my kid to have a celebrity's name.  Everyone will think you named her after Halle Barry.
Zoe - another great, but overused, name
Ella - beautiful, simple, elegant
Kaelyn - okay
Abby - very pretty.  This was on my list of names for daughter #2, but it didn't go as well with our last name.
Autumn - cute but cliche
Olivia - another great name (gave it to daughter #3 as a middle name to honor my grandmother)



You've chosen some lovely names.  Can't really go wrong with any of them!  :)



</answer>

<answer>



Rachel - 4/10



It's common.



Alexa - 0/10
Alexa is a nickname, not a name. Alexandra or Alexandria would be better.



Halle - 0/10
Hailey? Common and popular.



Zoe - 2/10
Popular and common.



Ella - 2/10
More of a nickname.



Kaelyn - 0/10
Looks made up.



Abby - 0/10
Abby is a nickname, not a name. It won't age well. Abigail with the nickname Abby would be lovely.



Autumn - 0/10
Autumn is a season, not a name.



Olivia - 2/10
Pretty but common and popular.



</answer>

<category>



Pregnancy & Parenting



Baby Names



</category>



<question from>



Dorian
Member since: 25 September 2008
Total points: 2407 (Level 3)



Contributing In:



Baby Names



</question from>



<question>



What are some good boy names for a girl?



I'm looking for boy names for a girl.  I prefer masculine names for a girl, maybe with a more traditional feminine middle name.  I put a list of the ones I like below but would love more suggestions.  Please no really cutesy or misspelled names - think more of how would the name sound for a CEO or an attorney.  Thanks!!



Riley Emerson
Avery Fiona
Emerson Willa
Elliot Eleanor
Spencer Jane
Holden Spencer
Ainsley Kiera



</question>



<additional details>



Aubrey - WOW, I'd see somebody about that anger issue if I were you.  And if you had read my question, you'd notice I never used the word unisex.  I know the names I've chosen aren't unisex, that's why I said masculine.



And I don't know if you have an issue with your name or not but let’s not stereotype or make generalizations.  Not all girls with masculine names grow up to hate them.  I have a masculine name and I've always loved it - still do.  So while some girls named Elliot grow up hating their names, so do some girls named Amy.  It's just a matter of the child's personality - which you cannot guess when the child's newborn.



And I didn't ask for criticism or a huge rant.  Just name suggestions.  If you don't have any fine - but there's no reason to be so rude.



For the record (just because a few people mentioned it) I really really want a daughter.  I'll (of course) love a son but will be a little disappointed if I don't have a girl.



Beverly - thanks for the input.  Personally, I think it would only be sexist if I thought boys were fundamentally better than girls - which I don't.  It's just a matter of taste - simple as that.  I like masculine names for girls.  For boys I like very old fashioned traditional names.  To each their own – that’s the beauty of living in a pluralist society.



And Reese Witherspoon is the perfect example of the fact that personality doesn't always match a person's name.  Obviously Reese didn't like Laura (yet it's a traditional girly name) so she chose to go with her middle name (she has two).  Good for her.  And if I name my daughter Holden and she grows up wanting to be called Felicity - good for her too and I'll respect her choice.



</additional details>



<answer from>



malbomb
Member since: 19 March 2008
Total points: 747 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



I don't mind Elliot, Avery or Riley for a girls name, but I would try to make those middle names more feminine. Riley Emerson and Holden Spencer are very masculine.



Elliot Clare sounds a lot softer than Elliot Eleanor, and it keeps it feminine.



Some may think its a bad idea to give a girl a boys name, but think about these women: Cameron Diaz, Reese Witherspoon, Drew Barrymore, the Australian Governer General is the highest ranked female in Australia and she has a masculine name - Quentin. They are all successful women with masculine names.



Edit: Beverly, you are extremely narrow minded. Just because you think a certain way, doesn't mean everybody should follow suit. Be thankful she isn't chosing a name like Nevaeh or Tiiffannii.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Thanks for your ideas.  Some of the other answers had great suggestions but I can't get over someone being so rude as to insult you in their answer.



While I don't agree with all of your answer (I'm leaning towards Riley Emerson) I really appreciate you sharing your opinion and ideas with me.



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



Aubrey ish male
Member since: 04 July 2008
Total points: 356 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



People insist on pushing these masculine names on poor little girls, because for their selfish reasons they don't care about the child, or the fact that they have to live their childhood with these names, always being mistaken for a boy, because their parents didn't care, they just thought it's cute. And by the time they're eighteen and can legally change their names, the damage is already done. All because of their arrogant, ignorant, selfish, unintellectual parents.



You're not breaking any gender barriers. Women aren't overcoming anything by having a boy's name. It doesn't make them stronger or smarter. That's all it is, a girl with a boy's name. It's pretty much saying "We wanted a boy but had a girl and decided to give a boy's name anyways" or girls aren't as good as boys so you gave them a boy's name so they will be better.



</answer>

How Does Hannah Grace/Ava Grace Sound Like A Prayer?

<answer from>



lt;3
Member since: 20 October 2007
Total points: 8656 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



Ava Grace - Ava is common and popular. She'll probably one of many in her class and because of it have to go by her last initial. Grace is common, dull, filler, and way way overused as a middle.



Hannah Grace - I love Hannah, but unfortunately it's common. I love Hannelore though. Grace is common, dull, filler, and way way overused as a middle. This combo is common.



Sophie Lauren - Sophie is a nickname, not a name. Sophia, although common, would be much much better with Sophie as a nickname. Lauren is pretty.



Natalie Victoria - I don't care for Natalie. Victoria is gorgeous.



Emily Madison - Emily is common, popular, and overused. She'll probably be one of many in her class and have to go by her last initial. Madison is a masculine boy's name and absolutely horrid for a little girl. It means Son of Maude. She's your daughter, not your son.



EDIT: Sophie /is/ a nickname. It's a nickname for Sophia. It's childish and won't age well. Give her Sophia with the nickname Sophia so when she is older she will have something sophisticated to go by. Because she will grow up. You're naming a child, not a doll.



</answer>



<answer from>



Rae Rae
Member since: 24 October 2008
Total points: 295 (Level 2)



</answer from>

4. Hannah Grace

<answer from>



Winterli...
Member since: 25 April 2008
Total points: 4535 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



ok normal names



but



Emily This name is wildly popular and has been the #1 for baby girls born in the US and Canada for several years! Do not use this name unless you want her to be Emily P. (or whatever) all throughout her life.



Madison is, to me, incredibly popular, trendy and will date and age with a bearer horribly, automatically pinning them to the 2000's era, much like we associate Jessica with the 1980's. SON stands out so blatantly in this name, that I fail to find its appeal as a girls name. "Strong" girls name do not need masculine elements. Girls names can be strong on their own because of the very reason they are girls names.



Furthermore, I dismiss most "daughter of" meanings. The name says SON right in it, and any "daughter of" meanings for this name were simply probably invented to justify its use on a girl. And even in the movie Splash, where the craze for this name probably first originated it, it was taken from a *street sign*.



Even for a male, I hesitate with this name, and would only use it in the Middle name slot, if a family connection exists with the name.



</answer>

Heraklit...

</answer from>



<answer>



I like the unconventional and beautiful sounding name Ava Grace, whose first part Ava means "life", "desired" or "radiant one." Ava is also the name of a German poetess: Frau Ava of Göttweig or Ava of Melk (c. 1060–7 February 1127).



Sources:



http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ava_(given_...
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ava_(poet)



The remaining names on the list are nice, but in my opinion two of them should be rather avoided: Sophie Lauren and Natalie Victoria. It's well-known that the spelling of "Sophie Lauren" is closely similar to "Sophia Lauren", a famous actress. Concerning the name "Natalie Victoria", it comprises two common female given name: Natalie and Victoria, and would easily be subject to ridicule by school kids, which is derogatory for your daughter.



</answer>



<answer from>

Total points: 4228 (Level 4)

<answer>



Emily is a nice name, not one I would ever personally use though. I don't care for Madison. It flows nicely. Both names are very popular, and I normally don't care for overly popular names. That's just my personal opinion though. Plus she's your daughter, not mine. You've allready named her and it doesn't matter what people think.



I'll rate the names on a scale of 1-10 (1=hate,10=love).



Ava Grace ~ 5 (Don't really care for it Ava, but Grace is nice. Emily and Ava do sound nice together though.)



Hannah Grace ~ 8 (I love Hannah! Grace is cute, too. Emily and Hannah sound nice together.)



Sophie Lauren ~ 3 (It doesn't flow well. And I personally don't care for Sohpie. I think Lauren Sophia would sound gorgeous though! Emily and Sophie sound ok together.)



Natalie Victoria ~ 9 (Lovely combination. Feminine and elgant. Emily and Natalie sound great together.)



Good luck, God Bless, and Congratulations! =)



EDIT: I think it was a lovely idea for you to name your daughter after your cousin who passed away. I am sorry for your loss.



Isobel is a very pretty name too! Is Isobel an option for this baby?



Also to whomever said Sophie is a nickname ~



While Sophie IS a nickname for Sophia, it is also a name in itself. Just because YOU personally prefer Sophie as a nickname does not mean it's not a name. I agree that Sophia is prettier with Sophie as a nickname also, but it's her baby and you're being rude by some of your comments, especially about Madison. It's her cousin that passed away for goodness sakes!



</answer>

<question>



I would like middle name suggestions for some names please? (ALL GIRLS)?



Here are a few of my faves that I don't have middle names for. Suggestions would be greatly appreciated. I would like it to flow as well as possible. Also, I am normally not a fan of what are considered "filler" middle names. But if it's "filler" and you think I might like it, go on a suggest it. But mainly, I am looking for somewhat creative middle names. It doesn't have to be way out there. I do like some simple names as middle names such as Joy (girl) or George (boy).



Keona (Kee-oh-nuh)



Brooklynn (Brook-lin)



Clara (Clare-uh)



Emeline/Emmaline/Emmeline (Em-uh-line)



Leona (Lee-oh-nuh)



Marcella (Mar-sell-uh)



Makenna (Muh-kenna)



I will pick a best answer! Thank you for answering =)



</question>

<answer from>



Kiwi A

<answer>



I quite like Cecelia, Vera and Frederick but the rest are too common for me. Depends which ones YOU like!



My grandparents names are:
(maternal)
Hilda Gertrude (Bleech!!)
Douglas Clement Arthur (not my style)
Paternal:
Janet Rhonda Rapley (the rapley is kinda cool and after some ancestor)
Cuthbert (not sure of middle name)



THe only name i would consider from those is Janet. Maybe the Rapley as a middle name but i don't know the history behind it and i'd want to. If my granddad Doug didn't have such a terrible name i'd use his as he was my fav grandparent.



Where i live (italy) it is customary to name kids after their grandparents, which i don't agree with. A new person needs their own name. If you want to honour an ancestor (especially if they are dead) and you like the name then that is great. If you HAVE TO call your kids after the grandparents that is just awful to me.



My daughters (paternal) grandparents are called Salvatore and Serafina, both awful names in my opinion. Luckily when she was born she already had a female cousin named after the grandmother so i was not obliged (although it was still possible) to use the GMs name. Luckily she was not a boy, as even though i never would have used Salvatore there would have been a lot of family pressure to do so. Now i'm pregnant with a boy but luckily there is already another baby boy named Salvatore so the obligation has been taken out of this name too. Whew!



</answer>

<question from>



laura
Member since: 25 March 2008
Total points: 2772 (Level 4)



</question from>



<question>



Unique girls' names I'm unsure about?



These aren't names I'm planning on for future children, just names that I can't decide whether they sound like dogs' names or really pretty unique names that bring to mind gorgeous quirky girls to suit them!!



Tosca and Lux.



Lux I heard from 'The Virgin Suicides' (slightly morbid inspiration I know - but Kirsten Dunst is so pretty in that film and the name seems to really suit her, do you like it? plus it means 'light' which is rather lovely. But it's also rather a harsh sound perhaps?)
And Tosca I met a little 7 year old who was so beautiful with long blonde hair and I couldn't decide whether it really suited her or just sounded like a dog's name and wasn't very flattering for her!



What do you think of them?



</question>



<answer from>



Sedora
Member since: 03 July 2008
Total points: 10177 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Languages



Baby Names



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



I love Tosca, and like Lux for the same reason you do.



Tosca is one of those beautiful opera names that never quite took off, unlike Aida, for example. Director Floria Sigismondi named her daughter Tosca. Floria's parents were opera singers and named her for the main character in the opera too: Floria Tosca.



I love how she then gave the character's surname to her daughter. :)



</answer>



<asker's comment>



I didn't know that about the opera actually - that's a very nice origin for it! Floria is lovely too. Thanks!



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



jillian m
Member since: 21 October 2008
Total points: 312 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I like them both, and sometimes the real associations can help you fall in love with a very unusual name.  I once met a 7 year-old girl, blond and full of life named DaVinci.  It suited her so well.  Everyone else hates the name but I adore it.



</answer>



<answer from>



randomdr...
Member since: 24 August 2008
Total points: 1822 (Level 3)



</answer from>

apparently jo whiley (yeah, i don't know her either) named her baby coco lux. i answered a question on it a few days ago. i think it's a stupid name.



lux is a harsh sound i agree. and tosca reminds me of crackers.



</answer>

<question from>



sinattaj
Member since: 28 October 2008
Total points: 98 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



"Nicsa", Does it sounds boyish for a baby girl's name?



We are going to have a cute baby girl in xmas, and finally after all those flame wars on baby's name we have a few candidates now.



One of those is Nicsa which means "Like Goodness" in Persian.
We might to know that the name sounds girlish in English or not.



Feel free to suggest some other names or tips on us.



</question>



<additional details>



P.S. "Nicsa" pronounced Neek-Sah and is a unique name because we made it by following correct Persian language grammar. "Nic/k" means "Goodness; Wellness" and "Sa" is a Persian suffix which means "Like ..." and there is some examples of names made by this rule are:



Mah-Sa (Like moon)
Dor-Sa (Like pearls)
Gol-Sa (Like flowers)
Pari-Sa (Like a fairy)
Avi-Sa (Like Water)
Zar-Sa (Like Gold)



and so on.



We think that Persian language is very rich language to make a unique and nice names.



</additional details>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>

Meanwhile, I found NICSA only as an acronym. None of these warrant using the name for a child. Based only on the following, I'd have to say don't use the name.



National Investment Company Service Association
Northern Ireland Countryside Staff Association
Northwest Interinstitutional Council on Study Abroad
Northern Ireland Child Support Agency
National Initiative to Combat Sexual Assault
Negocios Internacionales De Colombia SA

<answer>



Congrats on the baby!!!



I am Persian, and never heard of that name...How about Niku or Nikka?



As for other names... here are some that mean beautiful:



Mahdis "Beautiful like the moon"
Nika "Good, elegant, beautiful"
Nikoo "Good, beautiful"
Niku "Good, beautiful"
Jamila "beautiful"
Nadia "beautiful blossom/girl"
Rana "Behold; beautiful to gaze upon"
Rayan "Beautiful, exuberant"



Shahla "Beautiful eyes"
Shakila "Beautiful"



Shirin "Pretty, nice"
Zayna "Beauty"
Zohra "Beauty"



Some other ones:



Sona - Prayer
Sanam - Lover
Paniz - Sugar
Asal - Honey
Bita - unique
Almas - pearl
Kiana - Elements of nature. ie : earth, wind ,fire, etc.



Lily/Lili - A flower
Mina- Enamel,blue glass
Minoo- Paradise, heaven
Pardees - Paradise
Sanaz - A flower
Sussan/Soussan- A flower, Lily of the valley



My favorites are Nadia, Kiana and Sanam.



All the best to you and your family.

<question from>



My name Isobel.
Member since: 16 February 2008
Total points: 6747 (Level 5)



</question from>



<question>



What do you think of this girl name?



Léonie ("leh oh nee")



It comes from the word leo which means lion.



</question>



<additional details>



I'd use Léonie or Leonie, but I'd always say "leh oh nee"  The first is French, the second, German and they are pronounced the same basically.  I'm leaning more toward Léonie b/c ppl would be much less inclined to say "lee oh nee"



</additional details>



<answer from>
Member since: 21 October 2008
Total points: 316 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



I love it! I think Léonie looks better, and would be easier for people to pronounce.



I have a similar name on my list, Leona, and it also means lion. If I have a girl this time, I'll probably name her Leona because it's similar to my husband's name.



Anyways, I think the name is gorgeous.



-Beverly



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Thanks!  Leona is pretty too!  It sort of reminds me of Fiona and Viona, which I also really like.



I'll go with Léonie with the accent.  I think you're right about it helping with the correct pronunciation.



</asker's comment>

Member since: 21 August 2008
Total points: 2740 (Level 4)

<answer>

With the accent mark I would recognise how you pronounce your childs name, unfortunately not everyone gets it. good luck

<answer from>



libra.lo...
Member since: 20 February 2008
Total points: 1718 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



No, I know a male Raine. I love the name!



However, I suggest you don't LEGALLY change your name straight away; instead ask friends and family to identify you as Raine. This way, you will get used to being known the name and also be able to decide whether you really like it.



</answer>

Nathan Edward does sound like a very 'normal' name though (not sure if that is what you are after or not!).



I like the nickname Nate.



Not so fond of Edward. You could always change the middle name to be something a bit 'different' if you are worried about Nathan being too common.  But if your husband likes it, how often do you use middle names anyway?



Also depends on your surname. I'm not using Nathan as a name for my son (due in Jan) as our lastname starts with N and uses lots of the same letters so sounds a bit funny to me.



</answer>



<answer from>



kelly758...
Member since: 23 August 2008
Total points: 520 (Level 2)



</answer from>

<question>



Are these cute names for triplets ?



so last month i posted a question because my friend is having triplets all girls. only 2 weeks to go and she has change the names again.



her name is Haylie and her Hubby is George. there first son is name Zachary.



the name she likes...



Ella Kate
Chloe Tayla
Leah Jane

<answer>



Ella Kate is ok but to me sounds a bit simple and old-fashioned. My recommendations would be Ella Katherine, Ellie Katherine or Eleanor Katherine.



Chloe Tayla is ok but Im not sure about Tayla. I would recommend Chloe Layla or Chloe Maya



Leah Jane: I'll be honest with you, I just don't like the name Leah, don't know why but its just never been a name I've liked. So I wouldn't recommend it. Jane is a bit over used as a middle name also. personally i think its a bit  boring.

<answer from>



Jennaem
Member since: 01 June 2008
Total points: 831 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



They're really great choices.
When picking names for triplets I think it's important that they all have the same number of syllables, preferably not loads otherwise it's a bit of a mouthful. These are really beautiful.
For a little suggestion, why not vary them slightly by switching Ella and Leah's middle names? I think Ella Jane and Leah Kate sound better.



</answer>
